In this lesson, we'll explore Japanese phrases for expressing proficiency in languages, including "I speak," "I'm learning," and "I don't understand."
From your previous lessons, you're familiar with expressing identities, occupations, and nationalities, so today we'll take a step ahead.
We'll begin with the phrase "I speak," in Japanese is

. The literal translation for this sentence is "I will speak". However, in conversational Japanese, it can also mean "I speak". Let's break it down.
The first word,

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang: is a particle used to mark the topic of the sentence, it's similar to the English word "as for". The last part,

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang: , means "will speak" or "speak". So again, "I speak" translates as

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang:
.
Now, to specify the language that you speak, we place the language before the phrase we just learned. For instance, "I speak English" is:

voice.name: en-US-RyanMultilingualNeural
voice.lang:
means "English". So the full sentence translates to "Regarding me, I speak English."
Moving on to "I'm learning," which in Japanese is

voice.lang: means "I" as we learned before, and

voice.lang: means "am learning". So, "I'm learning English" for example, translates to:
